title: 107_s2449
content: The Act titled "Federal Responsibility for Immigrant Health Act of 2002" allows federal payments under Medicaid for emergency medical conditions of certain aliens. The Social Security Act is amended to include necessary care and services for emergency medical conditions, pregnancy-related services, and communicable disease testing or treatment for certain aliens. Additionally, states have the option to eliminate residency requirements for these aliens under Medicaid. The Social Security Act is amended to include necessary care and services for emergency medical conditions, pregnancy-related services, and communicable disease testing or treatment for certain aliens. States have the option to eliminate residency requirements for these aliens under Medicaid. The amendments apply to medical assistance provided on or after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens. Funding for emergency health services for undocumented aliens is amended to provide $25,000,000 for fiscal years 1998 through 2001 and $50,000,000 for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. State allotments are determined by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Secretary will compute an allotment for the 15 States with the highest percentage of undocumented aliens for fiscal years 2003 through 2007, based on the ratio of undocumented aliens in each State to the total available amount. The allotment for each State is based on the percentage of undocumented aliens in the State compared to the total percentage for all States. Any unspent allotment in a fiscal year can be used in the following year. The percentage of undocumented aliens in a State is determined using the most recent estimates of illegal residents. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to require funds to assist hospitals and providers of emergency health services to undocumented aliens. The percentage of undocumented aliens in each State is determined based on the most recent estimates of illegal residents. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to require funds to assist hospitals and providers of emergency health services to undocumented aliens in areas impacted by health costs related to undocumented aliens. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to provide emergency health services to undocumented aliens in areas impacted by health costs related to them, based on hospital payments under the State plan or an alternative proxy for measuring services provided. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to provide emergency health services to undocumented aliens in areas impacted by health costs, using hospital payments or alternative proxies to measure services provided by eligible hospitals and related providers. Definitions and special rules apply, including the meaning of 'hospital,' 'provider,' and the relationship between providers and hospitals in furnishing emergency health services. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to provide emergency health services to undocumented aliens in areas impacted by health costs. Providers furnishing emergency health services to individuals also receiving services from hospitals are considered related. Amounts paid under this subsection cannot substitute federal payments made under title XIX of the Social Security Act or be used by a state for other purposes. The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to provide emergency health services to undocumented aliens in areas impacted by health costs. The amendments allow reimbursement to States for emergency medical services under title XIX of the Social Security Act, effective from fiscal year 2003. Allowing states and localities to offer healthcare to all individuals. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to exclude health benefits provided to individuals from the definition of assistance. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 is amended to exclude health benefits provided to individuals from the definition of assistance. The amendments specify that health care furnished before, on, or after the date of enactment of the Act will not be considered as assistance if provided by a State or local government agency or through appropriated funds.
